prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not changing the movie that I chose for my birthday.
so this happened a while ago and I'm curious if I was the asshole.

It was just before my 20th birthday and I decided I wanted to see a movie as my birthday party/gift to myself, I discovered that How to Train Your Dragon 3 was out so I thought id go see it. 

I posted on the group chat the date and time of the movie and asked if anybody wanted to join me for a birthday movie. I said its completely optional if you want to join me. 

most of the group agreed and I was happy. 
That was until one of them said why don't we pick a different movie, I replied saying that it was my birthday and it's the movie I picked, we could see another movie on another day if you want, but I really want to see How to Train Your Dragon. 

After realising they wouldn't change my mind they told me they weren't coming and stopped talking in the group chat. 

I'm now unsure if I should have changed the movie or not.

AITA?

and just incase anyone asks, I like how to train your dragon because it's a good movie. 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the person who wrote the AITA scenario is in the wrong. The situation is about choosing a movie for their birthday and someone else getting upset and not showing up.

First, the person planned to see How to Train Your Dragon 3 for their 20th birthday. They posted in a group chat, saying it's optional if others want to join. Most people agreed, but one person suggested a different movie. The author stood by their choice, explaining it's their birthday and they wanted that movie. The person who suggested another movie then backed out and stopped participating.

I need to evaluate if the author is wrong. The key points here are: it was the author's birthday, they made it clear the movie was their choice and others weren't obligated to come. The friend wanted a different movie but then chose not to attend. The author didn't force anyone to come; they just invited people. The friend's reaction seems to be about not getting their way, which might be their own issue. The author had the right to choose their own birthday activity. So the answer is likely B, the author isn't in the wrong.
